@@ -0,0 +1,17 @@
+from django.conf import settings
+from django.conf.urls import url, include
+
+from normandy.control import views as control_views
+from django.contrib.auth.views import login, logout_then_login
+
+urlpatterns = []
+
+if settings.ADMIN_ENABLED:
+  urlpatterns += [
+      url(r'^control/', include([
+          url(r'^$', control_views.IndexView.as_view(), name='index'),
body_text: I putted around with namespaces when I was overthinking all the registration/auth stuff, and they seemed really useful. Except my impression was that you would use control as the namespace, and the url name would still just be index. Then the urls in your template would look like {% url 'control:index' %}.  I think the answer given here was pretty useful http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19171570/a-real-example-of-url-namespace  ?
body: I putted around with namespaces when I was overthinking all the registration/auth stuff, and they seemed really useful. Except my impression was that you would use `control` as the namespace, and the url name would still just be `index`. Then the urls in your template would look like `{% url 'control:index' %}`.  I think the answer given here was pretty useful http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19171570/a-real-example-of-url-namespace  ?
body_html: I putted around with namespaces when I was overthinking all the registration/auth stuff, and they seemed really useful. Except my impression was that you would use control as the namespace, and the url name would still just be index. Then the urls in your template would look like {% url 'control:index' %}. I think the answer given here was pretty useful http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19171570/a-real-example-of-url-namespace ?
